channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Quebec Wildfires Contribute to Extreme Fire Season in Canada
item.description: Massive plumes of smoke from hundreds of Canadian fires, enveloped millions in smoke, triggering dangerous air quality warnings in both countries and turning skies an ashen orange.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Liam Stack and Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: An aircraft dropping a mixture of water and fire retardant over a wildfire in Barrington Lake, Nova Scotia, last week.

item.title: Deliberate Explosion Inside Ukraine Dam Most Likely Caused Collapse, Experts Say
item.description: With Russia and Ukraine blaming each other for the collapse of the Kakhovka dam, experts say that an external attack or even structural failure might explain the disaster, but that it is not likely.
item.dc:creator: James Glanz, Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Peña

item.title: Darfur, Blighted by Genocide, Faces a New Catastrophe: War
item.description: Hundreds have been killed in the western Darfur region since the nationwide conflict in Sudan began, raising fears of protracted warfare in an area already torn by decades of genocidal violence.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A market in El Geneina on April 29. The city in West Darfur has experienced some of the most severe fighting outside of the capital, Khartoum.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s LIV Golf Deal Is a Triumph That Transcends Sports
item.description: The deal to merge LIV Golf with the PGA Tour is a big win for the oil-rich kingdom, headlining a banner week that also includes a visit from the American secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Ahmed Al Omran
item.media:description: The golf deal, if it goes forward, represents an enormous victory for Saudi Arabia and its de facto leader, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, in the country’s bid to become a major player in global sports.

item.title: Flood Rescuers Press On in Southern Ukraine After Dam Disaster
item.description: As residents sought safety from engulfed communities, President Volodymyr Zelensky warned that hundreds of thousands could lack drinking water.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Prince Harry Testifies He Was ‘Stalked for Over a Decade’ by Paparazzi
item.description: Harry faced a second day of questioning over his accusation that a British newspaper group hacked his cellphone more than a decade ago. A former tabloid editor also took the stand.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Britain’s Prince Harry and his lawyer, David Sherborne, right, leave the Royal Courts of Justice in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Rishi Sunak to Talk Tech With Biden, but Ukraine Is Likely to Surface
item.description: While economic corporation the challenges posed by artificial intelligence are on the agenda, Russia’s invasion presents immediate threats.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Prince Harry Ends Testimony on Tabloid Case
item.description: Prince Harry ended his testimony in his trial against a newspaper group. “For my whole life, the press have misled about me and covered up their wrongdoing,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Prince Harry leaving court in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Pope Francis Is Out of Surgery With ‘No Complications,’ Vatican Says
item.description: The 86-year-old pontiff had the medical procedure to treat a hernia.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving to lead his weekly general audience in St. Peter’s Square in Vatican City on Wednesday.

item.title: U.N. Tribunal Finds Defendant in Rwanda Genocide Unfit to Stand Trial
item.description: Judges at a special U.N. tribunal said they would create a procedure to allow them to hear evidence in the case against Félicien Kabuga, who has dementia, without the possibility of a conviction.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Mict/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: An image taken from handout video showing Félicien Kabuga at a hearing last year in The Hague. He is accused of encouraging and bankrolling the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.

item.title: Sudan War: What We Know About the Conflict, and Why It Hasn’t Stopped
item.description: The strategically important northeastern African country has been consumed by weeks of fighting between two military factions. Sudanese and foreigners have been fleeing in droves, but many people are stuck.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Smoke rose in Omdurman, Sudan, as fighting broke out on April 15 between two rival military factions in Khartoum, the capital, and around the country.

item.title: What We Learned From Prince Harry’s First Day in Court
item.description: The self-exiled British prince did not mince words as he finally got his day in court.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prince Harry leaving the High Court in London on Tuesday after giving evidence.

item.title: Europeans Now See Russia as an Adversary, but Not China, Poll Says
item.description: An extensive poll of 11 European countries finds citizens less eager for competition and rivalry with China than Washington — or European elites — have become.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, during a welcoming ceremony in Beijing in April.

item.title: Bolsonaro to Face Trial Over Electoral Fraud Claims
item.description: Brazil’s former president is accused of spreading false information about the nation’s election systems. A conviction would block him from office for eight years.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Former President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil speaking in March, after his loss, at the Conservative Political Action Conference in March in National Harbor, Md.

item.title: Ukraine Flood Deepens Misery in War Zone
item.description: “We were getting used to the shelling, but I’ve never seen a situation like this,” said one woman rescued in Kherson after a dam upstream was destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stand up paddle through the water to rescue residents from a flooded neighborhood caused by the destruction of the Kakhovka dam in Kherson, in southern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: After Dam Destruction in Ukraine, Thousands Flee for Water and Shelter
item.description: As rescue efforts plucked people from rooftops, and offered fresh water and shelter, Turkey’s president called for an international investigation into what caused a dam to fail.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Paul Sonne and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evacuation operations in Kherson in southern Ukraine on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Dangerous Haze Across North America
item.description: Also, evacuations from flooding in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke from the wildfires blanketed New York City yesterday.

item.title: When Politics Saves Lives: a Good-News Story
item.description: The decision to fund medications to treat H.I.V.-AIDS patients in sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean flew in the face of expert advice. But the U.S. did it anyway.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief
item.media:description: President George W. Bush with Bono, the lead singer of U2, in 2006. Bono was among the activists who lobbied Mr. Bush for antiretroviral medications for people in sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean.

item.title: The Vaquita Hangs On: Drone Video Shows a Critically Endangered Porpoise in Mexico
item.description: The latest scientific survey of vaquitas, one of the planet’s most imperiled species, suggests that new conservation measures are working.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn

item.title: Turkey’s Lira Falls to New Low as a New Economic Policy Forms
item.description: The lira plunged 7 percent against the U.S. dollar, as a new finance minister promising “rational” economic policy takes charge
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Mehmet Simsek, Turkey’s new finance minister, is well regarded in financial circles.

item.title: What We Learned From Prince Harry’s Second Day of Testimony
item.description: Harry’s testimony was part of the lawsuit that he and three other plaintiffs have brought against three Mirror titles. The newspaper group has denied wrongdoing.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prince Harry and his lawyer, David Sherborne, right, depart High Court in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Dam Collapse Brings Floodwater to Kherson
item.description: Low-lying areas of Kherson were a panorama of water and floating debris. One man stood on a cabinet in his living room waiting for hours for help.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Kherson, in southern Ukraine, paddle-boarding while standing up on Wednesday to try to rescue residents in a neighborhood flooded by the destruction of the Kakhovka dam.

item.title: A Stunning Merger Angers Athletes
item.description: A professional golf merger is a victory for Saudi Arabia and another sign that money can overwhelm almost any other force in sports.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Dustin Johnson teed off on the 1st hole at a LIV golf tournament last year at Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, N.J.

item.title: Air Quality This Week Gives U.S. a Glimpse of the World’s Air Pollution
item.description: Air-quality readings like the ones expected across parts of New York State on Wednesday would not be seen as particular cause for alarm in some parts of the world.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Jin Yu Young and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A fisherman near smog-covered buildings on the north coast of Jakarta.

item.title: Traveling the World With Your Best Friend at Any Age
item.description: At 81 years old, Eleanor Hamby and Dr. Sandra Hazelip traveled from the icy shores of Antarctica to the rocky majesty of the Grand Canyon — in 80 days.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Sandra Hazelip, left, and Eleanor Hamby became social media sensations as they traveled the world, racking up millions of “likes” from followers.

item.title: Russia and Saudi Arabia’s Oil Partnership Shows Strain
item.description: Analysts said the countries’ mutual need to keep energy prices high would help them maintain close ties, despite signs that Moscow has undercut previous deals.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Christophe Viseux for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Manifa oil field in Saudi Arabia. The kingdom’s plan to slow production in order to raise oil prices has been complicated as Russia keeps its petroleum exports flowing.

item.title: How Sam Altman Stormed Washington to Set the A.I. Agenda
item.description: The chief executive of OpenAI, which makes ChatGPT, has met with at least 100 U.S. lawmakers in recent months. He has also taken his show abroad.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:description: Sam Altman, right, OpenAI’s chief executive, and Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, at a hearing last month. “The difference with Sam Altman is that he is having a conversation,” Mr. Blumenthal said.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The destruction of a major dam in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Destroyed Kakhovka Dam in Ukraine Floods War Zone and Forces Evacuations
item.description: Experts suspect an explosion collapsed the dam on the Dnipro River. Kyiv and Moscow blamed each other, and residents downstream were forced to evacuate to escape the cascading waves.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora, Haley Willis and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: The Nova Kakhovka dam in the Kherson region of Ukraine was breached early Tuesday.

item.title: Through Ties to Saudis, Golf Deal Promises Benefits to Trump
item.description: The new alliance between the PGA Tour and LIV Golf is the latest example of how the former president’s relationship with Saudi Arabia has yielded gains, and criticism, for both.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.media:description: LIV Golf brought three tournaments at courses belonging to the Trump family in 2023, another example of the close relationship between the former president and Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Dam Destroyed in Ukraine
item.description: Also, a victory for the Saudi-backed golf tour.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Planet Labs PBC, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A satellite image showing an overview of the damage on the Kakhovka dam in southern Ukraine on Tuesday.

item.title: Prince Harry, in Dramatic Testimony, Accuses Journalists of Phone Hacking
item.description: In a remarkable court scene, the prince took the stand for five hours to make his case that his phone was hacked by a newspaper group, as a lawyer for the defense grilled him about his claims.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Megan Specia
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Prince Harry arriving at court on Tuesday in London to testify as a plaintiff in a phone hacking civil trial.

item.title: Destroyed Dam Sends Ukrainians Fleeing for Shelter
item.description: Many Ukrainians have learned to live with occupation and shelling. On Tuesday a new menace began lapping at their doors.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Evelina Riabenko
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Was Aware of Ukrainian Plan to Bomb Nord Stream Pipeline Before Attack
item.description: The Washington Post reported on Tuesday that U.S. intelligence agencies were aware of plans to attack the Nord Stream pipelines three months before they were bombed.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: An intelligence summary showed that the United States and European allies had reason to believe even before the attack that Ukraine viewed the pipelines as a target.

item.title: Dam Destruction Threatens Crimea’s Water Supply, Russia Warns
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: Residents looked at a partly flooded area of Kherson on Tuesday after damage to the Kakhovka dam.

item.title: A Summer Without Arctic Sea Ice Could Come a Decade Sooner Than Expected
item.description: In a new study, scientists found that the climate milestone could come about a decade sooner than anticipated, even if planet-warming emissions are gradually reduced.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.category: National Snow and Ice Data Center
item.media:credit: Markus Rex, Alfred Wegener Institute, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Lighter-than-usual sea ice conditions at the North Pole in August 2020.

item.title: Prince Harry Says Tabloid Intrusion Caused His Chelsy Davy Breakup
item.description: In written testimony, the prince said his and Ms. Davy’s phones were repeatedly hacked while the two were dating.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Prince Harry and Chelsy Davy at a rugby match in London in 2009.

item.title: French Pension Plan Protests Erupt Again
item.description: After months of widespread protests failed to budge the government, opponents acknowledge that the chances of turning the tide now are slim.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Riot police used a water cannon on Tuesday to disperse demonstrators rallying in Rennes, in northwestern France, against government changes to pensions.

item.title: World Bank Projects Weak Global Growth Amid Rising Interest Rates
item.description: A new report projects that economic growth will slow this year and remain weak in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times
item.media:description: A factory in Give, Denmark. Rising interest rates may slow output in industries around the world, in both advanced and developing economies.

item.title: A Religious School That’s Also a Public School
item.description: Oklahoma’s decision to allow the Catholic church to operate a public school continues a winning streak for religious conservatives.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: St Isidore of Seville Catholic Virtual School

item.title: Read Prince Harry’s Written Statement to the Court
item.description: Prince Harry’s lawyers filed a statement with the High Court in London before he took the stand in his lawsuit against the Mirror newspaper group.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Prince Harry Wages War Against Tabloids Forced to Change, if Not Retreat
item.description: The U.K. news landscape has shifted since the prince says he was hacked more than a decade ago, with hefty legal settlements, prison time for journalists and the threat of regulation forcing change.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: The Sun, leading in 2020 with a story on Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, is part of a crowded field feeding celebrity news to the British public.

item.title: Storming a Trench Is Treacherous Business. Here’s How It’s Done.
item.description: Assaults on trenches can be stealthy, or deafeningly loud. Either way, they are nerve-racking. Here’s how one Ukrainian unit says it carried out a successful attack earlier this month.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukraine’s 93rd Mechanized Brigade firing a mortar at Russian positions from outside Bakhmut in May.

item.title: The Immigrant Experience in a Danish Butter Cookie Tin
item.description: Ubiquitous in immigrant households, the cookie tin might be a more apt metaphor for our journeys than the melting pot.
item.dc:creator: Raksha Vasudevan

item.title: Who Is David Sherborne, Prince Harry’s Lawyer?
item.description: The lawyer leading the courtroom arguments, David Sherborne, has taken on Britain’s tabloid press several times.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: David Sherborne, the lead lawyer in two of Prince Harry’s three current lawsuits, arriving at the High Court in London on Tuesday.

item.title: Kakhovka Dam in Ukraine Destroyed: What to Know
item.description: Thousands of residents fled rising floodwaters in southern Ukraine, a day after a dam on the Dnipro River was destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A screengrab from a video showing damage to the Kakhovka dam on Tuesday.

item.title: D-Day’s Historic Beaches Face a New Onslaught: Rising Seas
item.description: As climate change speeds coastal erosion in France, can memory be preserved if the famous landing sites of the Allied invasion disappear?
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wooden fencing has been installed to help retain sand on the dune in front of the Utah Beach Landing Museum in Ste.-Marie-du-Mont, France.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Signs of a counteroffensive in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Ukrainian Army’s 95th Air Assault Brigade in a wooded position targeting Russian forces in eastern Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Testimony Is Another Chapter in What Has Become a Life of Litigation
item.description: Prince Harry is getting his day in court as he takes on the tabloids that scrutinized his every move for years, even hacking his phone.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, are plaintiffs in no fewer than seven cases against the British tabloids and other media.

item.title: Biden Administration Shrugs Off Ukraine’s Attacks in Russia
item.description: For months, U.S. officials said cross-border operations risked a dangerous escalation. But those fears have ebbed.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in the Donbas region of Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: In New Ukrainian Attacks, U.S. Officials See Signs of a Counteroffensive
item.description: Kyiv has not formally announced the start of operations. But on Tuesday, Ukraine said the Russians had blown up a dam on the Dnipro River, potentially imperiling residents and the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Soldiers from Ukraine’s 95th Air Assault Brigade, with a lightweight British howitzer, targeted Russian positions in eastern Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Blinken to Talk to Saudis About Normalizing Ties With Israel
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will travel to Saudi Arabia to discuss the idea at a time when the politics in the three countries may make normalization difficult.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will visit Saudi Arabia this week.

item.title: Hackers Air Deep Fake Putin Speech Calling for Mobilization
item.description: The Kremlin said it was investigating what it called a “hack” after a bogus speech aired on some radio and television networks.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Kremlin on Thursday. His real voice appeared to have been used to create the fake announcement.

item.title: Biden Invites Allies to Washington as Fighting Intensifies in Ukraine
item.description: President Biden hosted Mette Frederiksen, the prime minister of Denmark, at the White House on Monday, and much of the discussion revolved around providing support to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Biden hosted Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark at the White House on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Is Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Here?
item.description: Also, train service resumes near India’s crash site.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Members of the 95th Air Assault Brigade operating a howitzer in the Donetsk region on Friday.

item.title: At Least 42 Are Dead and Thousands Are Displaced After Flooding in Haiti
item.description: Officials said that western portions of the country appeared to be the most affected by the flooding caused by heavy rain over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Residents crossing a submerged road in Léogâne, Haiti, about 23 miles west of the capital Port-au-Prince. Heavy rain caused widespread flooding over the weekend.

item.title: Poland Rejects E.U. Ruling, Restarting a European Feud
item.description: Poland’s justice minister called the E.U. court of justice “corrupt,” after it ruled a judicial overhaul was illegal. He vowed not to comply, though that could cost Poland billions.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Supporters and members of opposition parties take part in the “4th June March” in Warsaw, on Sunday.

item.title: Prince Harry Will Be the First British Royal to Testify Since Edward VII
item.description: Prince Harry’s expected courtroom testimony this week will be the first time that a prominent member of Britain’s royal family has been cross-examined in over 130 years.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: W. & D. Downey/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince Albert Edward, the eldest son of Queen Victoria, in 1898. Seven years earlier, he testified as part of a court case.
